Part 1Maintaining the court system
	The general duty
		The general duty
			The Lord Chancellor is under a duty to ensure that there is an efficientand effective system to support the carrying on of the business of—
				the Supreme Court,
				county courts, and
				magistrates' courts,
					and that appropriate services are provided for those courts.
			In this Part—
				“the Supreme Court” includes the district probate registries, and
				“magistrates' court” includes a committee of justices.
			In this Part references to the Lord Chancellor’s general duty in relationto the courts are to his duty under this section.
			The Lord Chancellor must, within 18 months of the coming into force of thissection, and afterwards annually, prepare and lay before both Houses ofParliament a report as to the way in which he has discharged his general dutyin relation to the courts.
	Court staff and accommodation
		Court officers, staff and services
			The Lord Chancellor may appoint such officers and other staff as appear tohim appropriate for the purpose of discharging his general duty in relation tothe courts.
			The civil service pension arrangements for the time being in force apply(with any necessary adaptations) to persons appointed under subsection (1) asthey apply to other persons employed in the civil service of the State.
			“The civil service pension arrangements” means—
				the principal civil service pension scheme (within the meaning of section 2of the Superannuation Act [1972 (c. 11)](/id/ukpga/1972/11?view=plain "Go toitem of legislation")), and
				any other superannuation benefits for which provision is made under or byvirtue of section 1 of the 1972 Act for or in respect of persons in employmentin the civil service of the State.
			Subject to subsections (5) and (6), the Lord Chancellor may enter into suchcontracts with other persons for the provision, by them or their sub-contractors, of officers, staff or services as appear to him appropriate forthe purpose of discharging his general duty in relation to the courts.
			The Lord Chancellor may not enter into contracts for the provision ofofficers and staff to discharge functions which involve making judicialdecisions or exercising any judicial discretion.
			The Lord Chancellor may not enter into contracts for the provision ofofficers and staff to carry out the administrative work of the courts unlessan order made by the Lord Chancellor authorises him to do so.
			Before making an order under subsection (6) the Lord Chancellor mustconsult—
				the Lord Chief Justice,
				the Master of the Rolls,
				the President of the Family Division, and
				the Vice-Chancellor,
					as to what effect (if any) the order might have on the proper and efficientadministration of justice.
			An order under subsection (6) may authorise the Lord Chancellor to enterinto contracts for the provision of officers or staff to discharge functions—
				wholly or to the extent specified in the order,
				generally or in cases or areas specified in the order, and
				unconditionally or subject to the fulfilment of conditions specified in theorder.
		Provision of accommodation
			The Lord Chancellor may provide, equip, maintain and manage such court-houses, offices and other accommodation as appear to him appropriate for thepurpose of discharging his general duty in relation to the courts.
			The Lord Chancellor may enter into such arrangements for the provision,equipment, maintenance or management of court-houses, offices or otheraccommodation as appear to him appropriate for the purpose of discharging hisgeneral duty in relation to the courts.
			The powers under—
				section 2 of the Commissioners of Works Act [1852 (c.28)](/id/ukpga/1852/28?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (acquisition byagreement), and
				section 228(1) of the Town and Country Planning Act [1990 (c.8)](/id/ukpga/1990/8?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (compulsoryacquisition),
					to acquire land necessary for the public service are to be treated asincluding power to acquire land for the purpose of its provision underarrangements entered into under subsection (2).
			“Court-house” means any place where a court sits, including the precinctsof any building in which it sits.
	Courts boards
		Establishment of courts boards
			England and Wales is to be divided into areas for each of which there is tobe a courts board.
			The areas are to be those specified by an order made by the LordChancellor.
			Each area established by an order under subsection (2) is to be known bysuch name as is specified in the order (but subject to subsection (4)).
			The Lord Chancellor may make orders altering the areas.
			“Altering”, in relation to an area, includes (as well as changing itsboundaries)—
				combining it with one or more other areas,
				dividing it between two or more other areas, and
				changing its name.
			Before making an order under subsection (4), the Lord Chancellor mustconsult any courts board affected by the proposed order.
			When making an order under subsection (2) the Lord Chancellor must haveregard to the desirability of specifying areas which are the same as—
				the police areas listed in Schedule 1 to the Police Act [1996 (c.16)](/id/ukpga/1996/16?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (division ofEngland and Wales, except London, into police areas), and
				the area consisting of the Metropolitan Police District and the City ofLondon police area.
			Schedule 1 contains provisions about the constitution and procedure ofcourts boards.
		Functions of courts boards
			Each courts board is under a duty, in accordance with guidance under thissection—
				to scrutinise, review and make recommendations about the way in which theLord Chancellor is discharging his general duty in relation to the courts withwhich the board is concerned, and
				for the purposes mentioned in paragraph (a), to consider draft and finalbusiness plans relating to those courts.
			In discharging his general duty in relation to the courts, the LordChancellor must give due consideration to recommendations made by the boardsunder subsection (1).
			If the Lord Chancellor rejects a recommendation made by a courts boardunder subsection (1) as a result of the board’s consideration of a finalbusiness plan, he must give the board his written reasons for so doing.
			The courts with which a courts board is concerned are—
				the Crown Court,
				county courts, and
				magistrates' courts,
					in the board’s area.
			The Lord Chancellor must prepare and issue the boards with guidance abouthow they should carry out their functions under subsection (1).
			The guidance may in particular contain provisions about the procedures tobe followed in connection with draft and final business plans.
			The Lord Chancellor may from time to time issue the boards with revisedguidance and revoke previous guidance.
			Guidance issued under this section must be laid before both Houses ofParliament.
	Abolition of magistrates' courts committees
		Abolition of magistrates' courts committees, etc.
			The Greater London Magistrates' Courts Authority (the magistrates' courtscommittee for Greater London) and all the magistrates' courts committees forareas of England and Wales outside Greater London are abolished.
			In consequence of that—
				England and Wales outside Greater London is no longer divided intomagistrates' courts committee areas, and
				the office of justices' chief executive is abolished.
			Schedule 2 (abolition of magistrates' courts committees: transfers) haseffect.
			The Justices of the Peace Act [1997 (c. 25)](/id/ukpga/1997/25?view=plain"Go to item of legislation") ceases to have effect.

The commission of the peace and local justice areas
	The commission of the peace for England and Wales
		There shall be a commission of the peace for England and Wales—
			issued under the Great Seal, and
			addressed generally, and not by name, to all such persons as may from timeto time hold office as justices of the peace for England and Wales.
	Local justice areas
		England and Wales is to be divided into areas to be known as local justiceareas.
		The areas are to be those specified by an order made by the LordChancellor.
		Each local justice area established by order under subsection (2) is to beknown by such name as is specified in the order (but subject to subsection(4)).
		The Lord Chancellor may make orders altering local justice areas.
		“Altering”, in relation to a local justice area, includes (as well aschanging its boundaries)—
			combining it with one or more other local justice areas,
			dividing it between two or more other local justice areas, and
			changing its name.
		Before making an order under subsection (4) in relation to a local justicearea the Lord Chancellor must consult—
			the justices of the peace assigned to the local justice area,
			any courts board whose area includes the local justice area or a part ofthe local justice area, and
			unless the alteration consists only of a change of name, any localauthorities whose area includes the local justice area or a part of the localjustice area.
		“Local authority” means—
			any council of a county, a county borough, a London borough or a council ofa district,
			the Common Council of the City of London, or
			a police authority established under section 3 of the Police Act [1996 (c.16)](/id/ukpga/1996/16?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") or theMetropolitan Police Authority.

Lay justices
	Meaning of “lay justice”
		In this Act “lay justice” means a justice of the peace who is not a DistrictJudge (Magistrates' Courts).
	Appointment of lay justices etc.
		Lay justices are to be appointed for England and Wales by the LordChancellor by instrument on behalf and in the name of Her Majesty.
		The Lord Chancellor—
			must assign each lay justice to one or more local justice areas, and
			may change an assignment so as to assign the lay justice to a differentlocal justice area or to different local justice areas.
		Every lay justice is, by virtue of his office, capable of acting as such inany local justice area (whether or not he is assigned to it); but he may do soonly in accordance with arrangements made by or on behalf of the LordChancellor.
		Rules may make provision about the training courses to be completed beforea person may exercise functions as a lay justice in any proceedings or classof proceedings specified in the rules.
		Subsection (3) is subject to section 12 (the supplemental list).
	Resignation and removal of lay justices
		A lay justice may resign his office at any time.
		The Lord Chancellor may remove a lay justice from his office by aninstrument on behalf and in the name of Her Majesty—
			on the ground of incapacity or misbehaviour,
			on the ground of a persistent failure to meet such standards of competenceas are prescribed by a direction given by the Lord Chancellor, or
			if he is satisfied that the lay justice is declining or neglecting to takea proper part in the exercise of his functions as a justice of the peace.
	The supplemental list
		A list, to be known as “the supplemental list”, must be kept in the officeof the Clerk of the Crown in Chancery.
		A lay justice whose name is entered in the supplemental list is notqualified as a justice of the peace to do any act or to be a member of acommittee or other body.
		No act or appointment is invalidated by reason of the disqualification of alay justice under subsection (2).
	Entry of names in the supplemental list
		Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the name of a lay justice who hasreached 70 must be entered in the supplemental list.
		The name of a lay justice who, when he reaches 70, is chairman of the layjustices assigned to a local justice area need not be entered in thesupplemental list until the term for which he is serving as chairman hasended.
		Where— 
			proceedings are, or are expected to be, in progress on the day on which thelay justice reaches 70, and
			the lay justice is exercising functions in those proceedings as a justiceof the peace,
				the Lord Chancellor may direct that the name of the lay justice need not beentered in the supplemental list until the proceedings have ended.
		The name of a lay justice must be entered in the supplemental list if—
			he applies for it to be entered, and
			the application is approved by the Lord Chancellor.
		The Lord Chancellor may direct that the name of a lay justice is to beentered in the supplemental list on the ground of incapacity.
	Removal of names from the supplemental list
		A person’s name must be removed from the supplemental list if he ceases tobe a justice of the peace.
		A person’s name must be removed from the supplemental list if—
			his name is in the list as a result of section 13(4) or (5), and
			the Lord Chancellor directs its removal.
	Lay justices' allowances
		A lay justice is entitled to payments by way of—
			travelling allowance,
			subsistence allowance, and
			financial loss allowance.
		Allowances under this section are to be paid by the Lord Chancellor atrates determined by him.
		A lay justice’s travelling allowance is an allowance in respect ofexpenditure—
			which is incurred by him on travelling, and
			which is necessarily incurred for the purpose of enabling him to performhis duties.
		A lay justice’s subsistence allowance is an allowance in respect ofexpenditure—
			which is incurred by him on subsistence, and
			which is necessarily incurred for the purpose of enabling him to performhis duties.
		A lay justice’s financial loss allowance is an allowance in respect of—
			any other expenditure incurred by reason of the performance of his duties,and
			any loss of earnings or social security benefits suffered by reason of theperformance of his duties.
		A lay justice is not entitled to a payment under this section in respect ofthe performance of his duties if—
			a payment of a similar kind in respect of those duties may be made to himapart from this section, or
			entitlement to the payment is excluded by regulations made by the LordChancellor.
		For the purposes of this section the performance of a lay justice’s dutiesincludes taking a training course provided by or on behalf of the LordChancellor.
		The Lord Chancellor may by regulations make provision about the way inwhich this section is to be administered and may in particular make provision—
			prescribing sums (including tax credits) that are to be treated as socialsecurity benefits for the purposes of financial loss allowances,
			prescribing the particulars to be provided for claiming payment ofallowances, and
			for avoiding duplication between payments under this section and underother arrangements where expenditure is incurred for more than one purpose.
	Records of lay justices
		The Lord Chancellor—
			must appoint a person to be keeper of the rolls for each local justicearea, and
			may appoint the same person to be keeper of the rolls for more than onelocal justice area.
		The keeper of the rolls for a local justice area must be notified, in suchmanner as the Lord Chancellor may direct, of—
			any assignment of a lay justice to the area,
			any change in an assignment of a lay justice as a result of which he ceasesto be assigned to the area, and
			the fact that a lay justice assigned to the area has ceased to be a justiceof the peace or that his name has been entered in or removed from thesupplemental list.
		The keeper of the rolls for a local justice area must ensure that anaccurate record is maintained of all lay justices for the time being assignedto the area.

Chairman and deputy chairmen and the bench
	Chairman and deputy chairmen: selection
		For each local justice area there is to be—
			a chairman of the lay justices assigned to the area, and
			one or more deputy chairmen of those lay justices,
				chosen by them from among their number.
		Rules may make provision—
			subject to subsection (3), as to the term of office of the chairman anddeputy chairmen, and
			as to the number of deputy chairmen to be elected for any area.
		The Lord Chancellor, or a person acting on his behalf, may authorise a layjustice to continue to hold office as chairman or deputy chairman for thepurposes of specified proceedings which are, or are expected to be, inprogress on the day on which the lay justice’s office would otherwise end.
		Any contested election for choosing the chairman or a deputy chairman is tobe held by secret ballot.
		Rules may make provision for the purposes of this section and may inparticular make provision—
			about the procedure for nominating candidates for election as a chairman ora deputy chairman;
			about the procedure at such an election.
	Rights to preside and size of bench
		If the chairman for a local justice area is present at a sitting or othermeeting of lay justices assigned to or acting in the area, he must preside.
		If, in the absence of the chairman, one or more of the deputy chairmen fora local justice area is present at a sitting or other meeting of lay justicesassigned to or acting in that area he (or the most senior of them) mustpreside.
		Neither subsection (1) nor subsection (2) applies if, in accordance withrules, the chairman or (as the case may be) the deputy chairman asks anotherof the lay justices to preside.
		Subsections (1) and (2) do not confer on the chairman or a deputy chairmana right to preside in court if, under rules, he is ineligible to do so.
		Subsections (1) and (2) do not confer on the chairman or a deputy chairmana right to preside—
			in a youth court or family proceedings court,
			at meetings of a committee or other body of justices of the peace which hasits own chairman, or
			at sittings when a District Judge (Magistrates' Courts) is engaged as suchin administering justice.
		Rules may make provision for the purposes of subsections (3) and (4) andmay in particular make provision—
			as to training courses to be completed by lay justices before they maypreside in court,
			as to—
			the approval of lay justices, in accordance with the rules, before they maypreside in court,
			the lay justices who may be so approved, and
			the courts to which the approval relates, and
			as to circumstances in which a lay justice may preside in court even thoughrequirements imposed under paragraph (a) or (b) are not met in relation tohim.
		Rules may also make provision—
			specifying the maximum number of lay justices who may sit to deal with acase as a magistrates' court, and
			as to the arrangements to be made for securing the presence on the bench ofenough, but not more than enough, lay justices.

Supplementary provisions about the bench
	Training, development and appraisal of lay justices
		Rules may (in addition to making provision under sections 10(4) and 18(6))make provision for, or in connection with, the training, development andappraisal of lay justices.
		Such rules may make provision for committees, constituted in accordancewith the rules, to have such functions as may be specified in the rules,including, in particular—
			providing advice and support to lay justices in connection with theirfunctions as lay justices;
			identifying the training needs of lay justices;
			appraising lay justices and reporting on the results of appraisals;
			giving or withholding approval for the purposes of section 18;
			advising the Lord Chancellor in relation to authorisations of lay justicesas members of family proceedings courts or youth courts;
			granting or revoking such authorisations on behalf of the Lord Chancellor.
		The Lord Chancellor must ensure that appropriate training and trainingmaterials are provided for lay justices with a view to enabling them to complywith requirements as to training imposed by rules under section 10 or 18 orthis section.
	Rules 
		In sections 10, 17, 18 and 19 “rules” means rules made by the LordChancellor.
		Before making any rules for the purposes of section 10, 17, 18 or 19 theLord Chancellor must consult—
			the Criminal Procedure Rule Committee,
			the Family Procedure Rule Committee, and
			the Magistrates' Courts Rule Committee.
	Duty to consult lay justices on matters affecting them etc.
		The Lord Chancellor must take all reasonable and practicable steps—
			for ensuring that lay justices acting in a local justice area are keptinformed of matters affecting them in the performance of their duties, and
			for ascertaining their views on such matters.

District Judges (Magistrates' Courts)
	Appointment etc.
		Her Majesty may, on the recommendation of the Lord Chancellor, appoint aperson who has a 7 year general qualification to be a District Judge(Magistrates' Courts).
		A District Judge (Magistrates' Courts) must, before acting as such, takethe oath of allegiance and judicial oath in accordance with the PromissoryOaths Act [1868 (c. 72)](/id/ukpga/1868/72?view=plain "Go to item oflegislation") and the Promissory Oaths Act [1871 (c.48)](/id/ukpga/1871/48?view=plain "Go to item of legislation").
		The Lord Chancellor may pay to a District Judge (Magistrates' Courts) suchallowances as he may determine.
		Any such allowances are in addition to the salary charged on and paid outof the Consolidated Fund under section 9 of the Administration of Justice Act[1973 (c. 15)](/id/ukpga/1973/15?view=plain "Go to item of legislation").
		The Lord Chancellor may remove a District Judge (Magistrates' Courts) fromoffice on the ground of incapacity or misbehaviour.
	Senior District Judge (Chief Magistrate)
		The Lord Chancellor—
			may designate one of the District Judges (Magistrates' Courts) to be SeniorDistrict Judge (Chief Magistrate), and
			if he does so, may designate another of them to be the deputy of the SeniorDistrict Judge (Chief Magistrate).
	Deputy District Judges (Magistrates' Courts)
		The Lord Chancellor may appoint a person who has a 7 year generalqualification to be a Deputy District Judge (Magistrates' Courts) for suchperiod as the Lord Chancellor considers appropriate (but subject to subsection(4)).
		A Deputy District Judge (Magistrates' Courts) must, before acting as such,take the oath of allegiance and judicial oath in accordance with thePromissory Oaths Act 1868 and the Promissory Oaths Act 1871.
		The Lord Chancellor may pay to a Deputy District Judge (Magistrates'Courts) such remuneration and allowances as he may determine.
		The Lord Chancellor may remove a Deputy District Judge (Magistrates'Courts) from office on the ground of incapacity or misbehaviour.
		During the period of his appointment, a Deputy District Judge (Magistrates'Courts)—
			is to act as a District Judge (Magistrates' Courts), and
			is to be treated for all purposes (apart from appointment, tenure,remuneration, allowances and pensions) as if he were a District Judge(Magistrates' Courts).
	District Judges (Magistrates' Courts) as justices of the peace
		A District Judge (Magistrates' Courts) is by virtue of his office a justiceof the peace for England and Wales.
		It is the duty of a District Judge (Magistrates' Courts) to act as ajustice of the peace in any local justice area in accordance with arrangementsmade by or on behalf of the Lord Chancellor.
	District Judges (Magistrates' Courts) able to act alone
		Nothing in the 1980 Act—
			requiring a magistrates' court to be composed of two or more justices, or
			limiting the powers of a magistrates' court when composed of a singlejustice,
				applies to a District Judge (Magistrates' Courts).
		A District Judge (Magistrates' Courts) may—
			do any act, and
			exercise alone any jurisdiction,
			which can be done or exercised by two justices, apart from granting ortransferring a licence.
		Any enactment making provision ancillary to the jurisdiction exercisable bytwo justices of the peace also applies to the jurisdiction of a District Judge(Magistrates' Courts), unless the provision relates to granting ortransferring a licence.
		This section does not apply to the hearing or determination of familyproceedings (as defined by section 65 of the 1980 Act).
		“The 1980 Act” means the Magistrates' Courts Act [1980 (c.43)](/id/ukpga/1980/43?view=plain "Go to item of legislation").

Justices' clerks and assistant clerks
	Justices' clerks and assistant clerks
		A justices' clerk is a person who is—
			appointed by the Lord Chancellor under section 2(1), and
			designated by the Lord Chancellor as a justices' clerk.
		A person may be designated as a justices' clerk only if he—
			has a 5 year magistrates' court qualification,
			is a barrister or solicitor who has served for not less than 5 years as anassistant to a justices' clerk, or
			has previously been a justices' clerk.
		The Lord Chancellor—
			must assign each justices' clerk to one or more local justice areas, and
			subject to subsection (4), may change an assignment so as to assign thejustices' clerk to a different local justice area or to different localjustice areas.
		Before changing an assignment of a justices' clerk so that he is no longerassigned to a local justice area, the Lord Chancellor must consult—
			the chairman of the lay justices assigned to that area, or
			if it is not possible or not practicable to consult the chairman, thedeputy chairman or such of the lay justices assigned to or acting in the areaas appear to the Lord Chancellor appropriate.
		An assistant to a justices' clerk is a person who is—
			appointed by the Lord Chancellor under section 2(1) or provided under acontract made by virtue of section 2(4), and
			designated by the Lord Chancellor as an assistant to a justices' clerk.
		The Lord Chancellor may by regulations provide that, subject to suchexceptions as may be prescribed by the regulations, a person may be designatedas an assistant to a justices' clerk only if he—
			has a 5 year magistrates' court qualification, or
			has such qualifications as may be prescribed by, or approved by the LordChancellor in accordance with, the regulations.
		In this Part “assistant clerk” is short for “assistant to a justices'clerk”.
	Functions 
		Rules may make provision enabling things authorised to be done by, to orbefore a single justice of the peace to be done instead by, to or before ajustices' clerk.
		Rules may also make provision enabling things authorised to be done by, toor before a justices' clerk (whether by virtue of subsection (1) or otherwise)to be done instead by, to or before an assistant clerk.
		An enactment or rule of law which—
			regulates the exercise of any jurisdiction or powers of justices of thepeace, or
			relates to things done in the exercise or purported exercise of any suchjurisdiction or powers,
				applies in relation to the exercise or purported exercise of any suchjurisdiction or powers by a justices' clerk by virtue of subsection (1) as ifhe were a justice of the peace.
		The functions of a justices' clerk include giving advice to any or all ofthe justices of the peace to whom he is clerk about matters of law (includingprocedure and practice) on questions arising in connection with the dischargeof their functions, including questions arising when the clerk is notpersonally attending on them.
		The powers of a justices' clerk include, at any time when he thinks heshould do so, bringing to the attention of any or all of the justices of thepeace to whom he is clerk any point of law (including procedure and practice)that is or may be involved in any question so arising.
		For the purposes of subsections (4) and (5) the functions of justices ofthe peace do not include functions as a judge of the Crown Court.
		Subsections (4) and (5) do not limit—
			the powers and duties of a justices' clerk, or
			the matters on which justices of the peace may obtain assistance from theirclerk.
		In this section “rules” means rules made by the Lord Chancellor.
		Before making any rules for the purposes of this section the LordChancellor must consult—
			the Criminal Procedure Rule Committee,
			the Family Procedure Rule Committee, and
			the Magistrates' Courts Rule Committee.
	Independence 
		A justices' clerk exercising—
			a function exercisable by one or more justices of the peace,
			a function specified in section 28(4) or (5) (advice on matters of law,including procedure and practice), or
			a function as a member of the Criminal Procedure Rule Committee or theFamily Procedure Rule Committee,
				is not subject to the direction of the Lord Chancellor or any other person.
		An assistant clerk who is exercising any such function is not subject tothe direction of any person other than a justices' clerk.

Places, dates and times of sittings
	Places, dates and times of sittings
		The Lord Chancellor may give directions as to the places in England andWales at which magistrates' courts may sit.
		In exercising his powers under subsection (1), the Lord Chancellor shallhave regard to the need to ensure that court-houses are accessible to personsresident in each local justice area.
		The Lord Chancellor may, with the concurrence of the Lord Chief Justice,give directions as to the distribution and transfer of the general business ofmagistrates' courts between the places specified in directions undersubsection (1).
		Directions under subsection (3) may, in particular, contain provision that,where a person is charged with an offence and is being required to appearbefore a magistrates' court, the place where he is required to appear is oneof the places described in subsection (5).
		The places are—
			a place in the local justice area in which the offence is alleged to havebeen committed;
			a place in the local justice area in which the person charged with theoffence resides;
			a place in the local justice area in which the witnesses, or the majorityof the witnesses, reside;
			a place where other cases raising similar issues are being dealt with.
		“The general business of magistrates' courts” does not include familyproceedings (as defined in section 65 of the 1980 Act).
		The Lord Chancellor may give directions as to the days on which and timesat which magistrates' courts may sit.
		Subject to any directions under subsection (7), the business ofmagistrates' courts may be conducted on any day and at any time.

Protection and indemnification of justices and justices' clerks
	Immunity for acts within jurisdiction
		No action lies against a justice of the peace in respect of what he does oromits to do—
			in the execution of his duty as a justice of the peace, and
			in relation to a matter within his jurisdiction.
		No action lies against a justices' clerk or an assistant clerk in respectof what he does or omits to do—
			in the execution of his duty as a justices' clerk or assistant clerkexercising, by virtue of an enactment, a function of a single justice of thepeace, and
			in relation to a matter within his jurisdiction.
	Immunity for certain acts beyond jurisdiction
		An action lies against a justice of the peace in respect of what he does oromits to do—
			in the purported execution of his duty as a justice of the peace, but
			in relation to a matter not within his jurisdiction,
				if, but only if, it is proved that he acted in bad faith.
		An action lies against a justices' clerk or an assistant clerk in respectof what he does or omits to do—
			in the purported execution of his duty as a justices' clerk or assistantclerk exercising, by virtue of an enactment, a function of a single justice ofthe peace, but
			in relation to a matter not within his jurisdiction,
			if, but only if, it is proved that he acted in bad faith.
	Striking out proceedings where action prohibited
		If an action is brought in circumstances in which section 31 or 32 providesthat no action lies, a judge of the court in which the action is brought may,on the application of the defendant, strike out the proceedings in the action.
		If a judge strikes out proceedings under subsection (1), he may if hethinks fit order the person bringing the action to pay costs.
	Costs in legal proceedings
		A court may not order a justice of the peace to pay costs in anyproceedings in respect of what he does or omits to do in the execution (orpurported execution) of his duty as a justice of the peace.
		A court may not order—
			a justices' clerk, or
			an assistant clerk,
				to pay costs in any proceedings in respect of what he does or omits to do inthe execution (or purported execution) of his duty as a justices' clerk orassistant clerk exercising, by virtue of an enactment, a function of a singlejustice of the peace.
		But subsections (1) and (2) do not apply in relation to any proceedings inwhich a justice of the peace, justices' clerk or assistant clerk—
			is being tried for an offence or is appealing against a conviction, or
			is proved to have acted in bad faith in respect of the matters giving riseto the proceedings.

Part 4Court security
	Court security officers
		A court security officer is a person who is—
			appointed by the Lord Chancellor under section 2(1) or provided under acontract made by virtue of section 2(4), and
			designated by the Lord Chancellor as a court security officer.
		The Lord Chancellor may by regulations make provision as to—
			training courses to be completed by court security officers;
			conditions to be met before a person may be designated as a court securityofficer.
		For the purposes of this Part a court security officer who is not readilyidentifiable as such (whether by means of his uniform or badge or otherwise),is not to be regarded as acting in the execution of his duty.
	Powers of search
		A court security officer acting in the execution of his duty may search—
			any person who is in, or seeking to enter, a court building, and
			any article in the possession of such a person.
		Subsection (1) does not authorise the officer to require a person to removeany of his clothing other than a coat, jacket, headgear, gloves or footwear.
		In this Part “court building” means any building—
			where the business of any of the courts referred to in section 1 is carriedon, and
			to which the public has access.
	Powers to exclude, remove or restrain persons
		A court security officer acting in the execution of his duty may exclude orremove from a court building, or a part of a court building, any person whorefuses—
			to permit a search under section 52(1), or
			to surrender an article in his possession when asked to do so under section54(1).
		A court security officer acting in the execution of his duty may—
			restrain any person who is in a court building, or
			exclude or remove any person from a court building, or a part of a courtbuilding,
				if it is reasonably necessary to do so for one of the purposes given insubsection (3).
		The purposes are—
			enabling court business to be carried on without interference or delay;
			maintaining order;
			securing the safety of any person in the court building.
		A court security officer acting in the execution of his duty may remove anyperson from a courtroom at the request of a judge or a justice of the peace.
		The powers conferred by subsections (1), (2) and (4) include power to usereasonable force, where necessary.
	Surrender and seizure of articles
		If a court security officer acting in the execution of his duty reasonablybelieves that an article in the possession of a person who is in, or seekingto enter, a court building ought to be surrendered on any of the grounds givenin subsection (3), he must ask the person to surrender the article.
		If the person refuses to surrender the article, the officer may seize it.
		The grounds are that the article—
			may jeopardise the maintenance of order in the court building (or a part ofit),
			may put the safety of any person in the court building at risk, or
			may be evidence of, or in relation to, an offence.
	Powers to retain articles surrendered or seized
		Subject to subsection (2), a court security officer may retain an articlewhich was—
			surrendered in response to a request under section 54(1), or
			seized under section 54(2),
				until the time when the person who surrendered it, or from whom it was seized,is leaving the court building.
		If a court security officer reasonably believes that the article may beevidence of, or in relation to, an offence, he may retain it until—
			the time when the person who surrendered it, or from whom it was seized, isleaving the court building, or
			the end of the permitted period,
			whichever is later.
		“The permitted period” means such period, not exceeding 24 hours from thetime the article was surrendered or seized, as will enable the court securityofficer to draw the article to the attention of a constable.
	Regulations about retention of articles
		The Lord Chancellor may by regulations make provision as to—
			the provision to persons—
			by whom articles have been surrendered in response to a request undersection 54(1), or
			from whom articles have been seized under section 54(2),
				of written information about the powers of retention of court securityofficers,
			the keeping of records about articles which have been so surrendered orseized,
			the period for which unclaimed articles have to be kept, and
			the disposal of unclaimed articles at the end of that period.
		“Unclaimed article” means an article—
			which has been retained under section 55,
			which a person is entitled to have returned to him,
			which has not been returned, and
			whose return has not been requested by a person entitled to it.
	Assaulting and obstructing court security officers
		Any person who assaults a court security officer acting in the execution ofhis duty commits an offence.
		A person guilty of an offence under subsection (1) is liable on summaryconviction to—
			a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale, or
			imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months,
				or to both.
		A person who resists or wilfully obstructs a court security officer actingin the execution of his duty commits an offence.
		A person guilty of an offence under subsection (3) is liable on summaryconviction to a fine not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale.

		Subject to subsection (2), this Act comes into force in accordance withprovision made by order by the Lord Chancellor.

	Extent 
		Subject to subsections (2) and (3), this Act extends only to England andWales.
		Subsection (1) does not apply to section 59(3), 90, 91, 100, 101, 102, 103,104, 105, 106 or 109.
